****************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post

International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=45292>


Highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Portugal
-----------------------------------------------------
General information
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 21 Dec 2021
Confirmed: 22 Dec 2021
Reported: 24 Dec 2021
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 5 Dec 2021
Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]
Serotype: H5N1
Nature of diagnosis: laboratory
This event pertains to the whole country.

Outbreak location: Obidos (Santa Maria), Obidos, Leiria
Started: 22 Dec 2021
Epidemiological unit: farm
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 18 100 / 7139 / 1459 / - / - / -
Affected population: HPAI H5N1 was confirmed in a commercial flock of turkeys. Stamping out started [24 Dec 2021].

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive

Control measures at event level
Domestic control measures applied: movement control inside the country; traceability; zoning; screening; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone
Domestic control measures to be applied: stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result
[National Institute for Agricultural and Veterinary Research] National Laboratory / Birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 23 Dec 2021 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[This outbreak has already been reported, in ProMED post 20211226.8700496.

A presentation on the avian influenza situation in Portugal during the PAFF [Plants, Animals, Food and Feed] Committee meeting on 15 Dec 2021 is available at <https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_prt.pdf>. - Mod.CRD

summary: PRO/MBDS> Avian influenza (64): Taiwan (Taipei) bird, H5N2, H5N1, OIE
content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (64): TAIWAN (TAIPEI) BIRD, HPAI H5N2, H5N1, SPREAD, OIE
************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this post:
[1] Yunlin, Pingtung, Nantou, Changhwa: poultry, HPAI H5N2
[2] Tainan: wild bird, HPAI H5N1

******
[1] Yunlin, Pingtung, Nantou, Changhwa: poultry, HPAI H5N2
Date: Fri 24 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=45251>


Highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), [Taiwan]
-----------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 16 Nov 2021
Confirmed: 20 Nov 2021
Reported: 24 Dec 2021
Last occurrence: 8 Nov 2021
Disease: highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry)
Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus
Genotype / serotype / subtype: H5N2 (HPAI) [clade 2.3.4.4.b]
Species: birds
Reason for notification: recurrence
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
Status: ongoing
Total cases: 20
This event pertains to the whole country

Summary of outbreaks
Total outbreaks (9)
Outbreak locations: Yuanchang Township [Yulin] (1), Erlun Township [Yulin] (2), Beigang Township [Yulin] (2), Gaoshu Township [Pingtung] (1), Zhushan Township [Nantou] (1), Sihu Township [Yulin] (1), Zhutang Township [Changhua] (1). See details of each outbreak at the source URL above.

Started: 16 Nov 2021
Total animals affected
Species / susceptible / cases / deaths / killed and disposed of / slaughtered or killed for commercial use / vaccinated / morbidity (calculated) / mortality (calculated)
Birds / 66 408 / 10 707 / 10 624 / 53 029 / 2755 / 0 / - / -

Epidemiology
Source of event or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: a novel H5N2 subtype highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus belonging to clade 2.3.4.4b was isolated from a duck carcass near the wetlands along the Zhuoshui river on 9 Aug 2021. Later, the same virus was found in poultry farming in both Yunlin County (6 farms) and Changhua County (1 farm near the Yunlin outbreak) under the annual active surveillance program for avian influenza. All farms have been thoroughly cleaned and disinfected after culling farmed birds. Adjacent farms within 3 km (1.8 mi) of the infected farms will be under strengthened surveillance for a period of 3 months. Suspected signs were observed in poultry carcasses during post-mortem inspection in the abattoir in Pingtung County. Samples were sent to the Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) for diagnosis. Novel H5N2 subtype HPAI was confirmed by the AHRI. The carcasses were destroyed and thorough cleaning and disinfection have been conducted in the abattoir. After tracing back to the farm of origin, any positive results will be included in follow-up reports. Samples from Nantou County were sent to the National Laboratory, Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) for diagnosis. Highly pathogenic avian influenza novel H5N2 subtype was confirmed by AHRI. The sampling spots in Nantou County were disinfected. Surrounding poultry farms within a 3 km (1.8mi) radius of the sampling spot are under intensified surveillance for 3 months.

Control measures at event level
Domestic control measures: movement control inside the country; disinfection; zoning
Applied: surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; stamping out
To be applied: screening

Diagnostic test results
Test name / category / test type / laboratory / species sampled / outbreaks / test date / result
Gene sequencing / genotyping / laboratory test / Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) National Laboratory / birds / 9 / [21 Nov to 17 Dec 2021] / positive
Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / nucleic acid detection / Laboratory Test / Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) National Laboratory / birds / 9 / [20 Nov to 16 Dec 2021] / positive

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MBDS

According to Taiwan news on 11 Dec 2021, "after an outbreak of the H5N2 bird flu was confirmed, a farm in Changhua County saw 16 778 of its chickens culled."
(<https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/4373009>)

"Emergence and intercontinental spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza A (HPAI) H5Nx virus clade 2.3.4.4 has resulted in substantial economic losses to the poultry industry in Asia, Europe, and North America. The long-distance migratory birds have been suggested to play a major role in the global spread of avian influenza viruses during this wave of panzootic outbreaks since 2013. Poultry farm epidemics caused by multiple introductions of different HPAI novel subtypes of clade 2.3.4.4 viruses also occurred in Taiwan between 2015 and 2017. The mandatory and active surveillance detected H5N3 and H5N6 circulation in 2015 and 2017, respectively, while H5N2 and H5N8 were persistently identified in poultry farms since their first arrival in 2015."
(<https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0236581>)

"The Zhuoshui River, also spelled Choshui or Jhuoshuei River, is the longest river in Taiwan. It flows from its source in Nantou County up to the western border of the county, subsequently forming the border between Yunlin County and Changhua County, with a total length of 203 km (126 mi). The river serves as an unofficial boundary between the north and south of Taiwan. It is dammed in its upper reaches by the Wushe and Wujie Dams, and further downstream by the Jiji Weir. The Zhuoshui River environment has in recent years been seriously degraded both by the construction of a dam across the river at Jiji and by the ongoing activities of the concrete industry."
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhuoshui_River>)
- Mod.TTM]

******
[2] Tainan: wild bird, HPAI H5N1
Date: Fri 24 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=45250>


Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Chinese Taipei
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 15 Dec 2021
Confirmed: 18 Dec 2021
Reported: 24 Dec 2021
Reason for notification: new strain in the country
Disease type: H5N1 (HPAI non. Plt)
Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus
Genotype / serotype / subtype: H5N1
Species: black-faced spoonbill
Status: ongoing
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
Total cases:2
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country

Summary of outbreaks
Total outbreaks:1
Outbreak locations: Annan District, Tainan
Started on: 15 Dec 2021
Epidemiological unit: other
Species / measuring unit / cases / deaths / killed and disposed of / slaughtered or killed for commercial use / vaccinated
Black-faced spoonbill (_Platalea minor_): Threskiornithidae-Phaethontiformes / Animal / 0 / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0
Total animals affected
Species / susceptible / cases / deaths / killed and disposed of / slaughtered or killed for commercial use / vaccinated / morbidity (calculated) / mortality (calculated)
Black-faced spoonbill (_Platalea minor_): Threskiornithidae-Phaethontiformes / 0 / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0 / - / -

Epidemiology
Source of event or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: on 15 Dec 2021, 2 _Platalea minor_ carcasses were found in Tainan City Sihcao Wildlife Refuge. H5N1 HPAI viruses were detected from the rotted _P. minor_ carcasses. The sequences of HA and NA genes showed 99-100% similarity to the sequences of H5N1 HPAI viruses identified in Korea and Japan analyzed by Animal Health Research Institute. According to the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code, intensified surveillance will be carried out following the HPAI outbreak for 3 months.

Control measures at event level
Wild control measures
Applied: zoning; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; disinfection
To be applied: screening

Diagnostic test results
Test name / category / test type / laboratory / species sampled / outbreaks / tested from / tested until / result
Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / nucleic acid detection / laboratory test / Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) National Laboratory / black-faced spoonbill / 1 / 18 Dec 2021 / - / positive
Gene sequencing / Genotyping / Laboratory Test / Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) National Laboratory / black-faced spoonbill / 1 / 18 Dec 2021 / - / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MBDS

[Influenza A viruses, in particular the H5 and H7 subtypes, have caused epizootic diseases in poultry for a long time. Wild aquatic birds and shorebirds form the natural virus reservoir. All influenza virus subtypes and almost all possible haemagglutinin/neuraminidase combinations have been detected in wild birds, whereas relatively few have been detected in humans and other mammals. In 1997, the emerging and spreading of the highly pathogenic strain H5N1 within Asia was supported by lack of hygiene in commercial poultry units and by the existence of live bird markets. During autumn 2005, migratory birds have been accused for spreading the infection along their flyways to Europe including Switzerland. For early detection of introduction to Europe, many countries have initiated surveillance programs for avian influenza in wild birds."
(<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18581906/>)

"The black-faced spoonbill (_Platalea minor_) is a species of wading bird in the ibis and spoonbill family Threskiornithidae, found in eastern Asia. This species has the most restricted distribution of the six spoonbill species, and it is the only one regarded as endangered. Spoonbills are large water birds with dorso-ventrally flattened, spatulate bills."
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black-faced_spoonbill>)

An image of a black-faced spoonbill can be seen at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Black_faced_spoonbill_at_Niigata.JPG>. - Mod.TTM

AVIAN INFLUENZA (34): INDIA, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, H5N8, UPDATE, OIE
*****************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[The following information summarizes the outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtypes H5N1 and H5N8 reported by India to the OIE, between 1 Dec to 26 Dec 2021. The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the source URL of each report. - Mod.CRD]

In this update:
[1] Kerala: poultry, HPAI H5N1
[2] Rajasthan: wild bird, HPAI H5N1
[3] Madhya Pradesh: wild bird, HPAI H5N8

******
[1] Kerala: poultry, HPAI H5N1
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=44623>


Kerala: Event started on 21 Nov 2021. HPAI subtype H5N1 was detected in a duck population. The outbreak is located in a village in Mankombu, Alappuzha, Kerala. A total of one outbreak (submitted) reported to date [26 Dec 2021]. The event is continuing.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 18 877 / 11 250 / 9750 / 9127 / - / -

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-SoAs
via
ProMED

******
[2] Rajasthan: wild bird, HPAI H5N1
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=44038>


Rajastahan: Event started on 6 Nov 2021. HPAI subtype H5N1 was detected in wild bird population. The outbreaks are located in the areas of Sambhar Lake, Sambhar, Jaipur, and Kaparda, Bilara, Jodhpur in Rajasthan State. A total of 2 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [26 Dec 2021]. The event is continuing.

Total animals affected:

<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=44023>


Madhya Pradesh: Event started on 28 Nov 2021. HPAI subtype H5N8 was detected in a wild bird population. The outbreak is located in an urban area (mutton market) in Agar, Agar Malwa in Madhya Pradesh State. A total of one outbreak (submitted) reported to date [26 Dec 2021]. The event is continuing.

summary: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (186): Taiwan, poultry, wild bird, HPAI H5N2, H5N1, OIE
content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (186): TAIWAN, POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N2, H5N1, OIE
***********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this post:
[1] Yunlin, Pingtung, Nantou, Changhwa: poultry, HPAI H5N2
[2] Tainan: wild bird, HPAI H5N1

******
[1] Yunlin, Pingtung, Nantou, Changhwa: poultry, HPAI H5N2
Date: Mon 27 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=45251>


Highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), [Taiwan]
-----------------------------------------------------
General information
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 16 Nov 2021
Confirmed: 20 Nov 2021
Reported: 24 Dec 2021
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 8 Nov 2021
Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus
Serotype: H5N2
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Summary of outbreaks
New outbreaks (9)
[The 9 outbreaks of HPAI subtype H5N2 (clade 2.3.4.4.b) occurred in the province of Taiwan in the following counties: Yunlin (6), Pingtung (1), Nantou (1), Changhwa (1). See details of each outbreak at the source URL above. - Mod.CRD]

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 66 408 / 10 707 / 10 624 / 53 029 / 2755 / 0

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: a novel H5N2 subtype highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus belonging to clade 2.3.4.4b was isolated from a duck carcass near the wetlands along the Zhuoshui River on [9 Aug 2021]. Later, the same virus was found in poultry farming in both Yunlin County (6 farms) and Changhua County (1 farm near the Yunlin outbreak) under the annual active surveillance program for avian influenza. All farms have been thoroughly cleaned and disinfected after culling farmed birds. Adjacent farms within 3 km of the infected farms will be under strengthened surveillance for a period of 3 months. Suspected signs were observed in poultry carcasses during postmortem inspection in the abattoir in Pingtung County. Samples were sent to the Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) for diagnosis. Novel H5N2 subtype HPAI was confirmed by the AHRI. The carcasses were destroyed, and thorough cleaning and disinfection have been conducted in the abattoir. After tracing back to the farm of origin, any positive results will be included in follow-up reports. Samples from Nantou County were sent to the National Laboratory, Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) for diagnosis. Highly pathogenic avian influenza novel H5N2 subtype was confirmed by AHRI. The sampling spots in Nantou County were disinfected. Surrounding poultry farms within a 3 km [2 mi] radius of the sampling spot are under intensified surveillance for 3 months.

Control measures applied in domestic: movement control inside the country; disinfection; zoning; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; stamping out.
Control measures to be applied in domestic: screening.

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result
Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) National Laboratory/ birds / gene sequencing / [21 Nov to 17 Dec 2021] / positive
Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) National Laboratory/ birds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / [20 Nov to 16 Dec 2021] / positive

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2] Tainan: wild bird, HPAI H5N1
Date: Mon 27 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=45250>


Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (inf with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Chinese Taipei
------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 15 Dec 2021
Confirmed: 18 Dec 2021
Reported: 24 Dec 2021
Reason for notification: new strain in the country
Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus
Serotype: H5N1
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, necropsy, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

New outbreaks (1)

Black-faced spoonbill (_Platalea minor_): Threskiornithidae-Phaethontiformes / 0 / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: on [15 Dec 2021] two _Platalea minor_ carcasses were found in Tainan City Sihcao Wildlife Refuge. H5N1 HPAI viruses were detected from the rotted _P. minor_ carcasses. The sequences of HA and NA genes showed 99-100% similarity to the sequences of H5N1 HPAI viruses identified in Korea and Japan analyzed by Animal Health Research Institute. According to the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code, intensified surveillance will be carried out following the HPAI outbreak for three months.

Control measures applied [in wild]: zoning; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; disinfection
Control measures to be applied [in wild]: screening

[A presentation on the avian influenza situation in Taiwan made during the 3rd Regional Workshop for Avian Diseases in Asia and the Pacific, 29-30 Sep 2021, is available at <https://rr-asia.oie.int/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/day-2-c-taipei.pdf>.

"Monitoring and controlling avian influenza at its poultry source is essential to decrease the virus load in susceptible avian species and the environment. Implementation of biosecurity measures, in line with OIE international standards, is key to secure the production sector and trade, to safeguard food security and the livelihoods of farmers (in particular in developing countries), as well as to limit the risk of human infection with avian influenza strains that have zoonotic potential." (<https://rr-asia.oie.int/en/projects/avian-influenza/>). - Mod.CRD]

summary: PRO/MENA> Avian influenza (25): Israel (Hazafon) poultry, wild bird, HPAI H5N1, spread / انفلونزا الطيور (25) : اسرائيل ، طيور برية، انتشار
content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (25): ISRAEL (HAZAFON) POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD / انفلونزا الطيور (25) : اسرائيل ، طيور برية، انتشار
**********************************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Poultry, wild birds
[2] Cranes, mass mortality, Hula Lake Reserve
[3] Table egg supply, public health concerns

******
[1] Poultry, wild birds
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Spiegel via The Limited Times [edited]
<https://newsrnd.com/tech/2021-12-26-avian-flu-is-spreading-in-israel--affecting-migratory-birds.SkDo2WLjt.html>


Israel is fighting the spread of bird flu. A spokeswoman for the Israeli Ministry of Agriculture confirmed that there was an outbreak in battery cages near the village of Margaliot in the north of the country on the border with Lebanon.

320 000 laying hens would therefore have to be killed, in addition to 244 000 hens that had already been killed a week ago.

Mass deaths had also previously been observed in other laying batteries in Israel.

"The Ministry of Agriculture is concerned that people could be infected by infected battery cells near homes," said a statement.

It is now expected that there will be a shortage of eggs on the Israeli market -- around 14 million eggs are missing every month due to bird flu.

The outbreak in Israel could have consequences for other regions.

According to media reports, about 20% of the cranes that come to Israel as migrating birds from southern Europe to stop there on their way to Africa are also affected by the disease.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MENA
via
ProMED

******
[2] Cranes, mass mortality, Hula Lake Reserve
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Times of Israel [edited]
<https://www.timesofisrael.com/5000-dead-cranes-counted-at-hula-lake-reserve-amidst-bird-flu-outbreak/>


Some 5000 dead cranes were counted on [Sun 26 Dec 2021] at the Hula Lake Reserve in northern Israel, amid an outbreak of avian flu that has also seen the culling of more than half a million chickens and turkeys.

The Hula Lake is the main gathering point for tens of thousands of wild birds that migrate through Israel twice yearly.

Nature authorities provide food there, to keep the birds away from farmers' crops.

Feeding is continuing since the outbreak of the H5N1 virus at the lake, and in chicken sheds at Moshav Margaliot on the Lebanese border, to try to keep the cranes from flying elsewhere and taking the virus with them.

During a tour of the area on [Sunday 26 Dec 2021] by staff of the Israel Nature and Parks Authority [INPA] and KKL-JNF Jewish National Fund, accompanied by Environmental Protection Minister Tamar Zandberg, another 250 dead cranes were seen in the Hula Valley outside of the reserve, and a further 30 were documented elsewhere, mainly in the Jezreel Valley.

A pelican with bird flu was reported in the Hefer Valley in central Israel and samples were being taken from dead birds at Kfar Ruppin in the Beit She'an Valley.

The INPA believes that the disease spread from Moshav Margaliot, via a truck driver who delivered food to the chicken coops there and then brought food to the Hula Reserve. A spokeswoman said there had never been such an avian flu outbreak among wild birds.

The Agriculture Ministry has said that the farmers on the moshav failed to report the outbreak in real time, allowing it to spread like wildfire.

The Hula Reserve will remain closed to the public until [1 Jan 2021].

Members of the public are advised to cook eggs and poultry meat thoroughly before eating, to avoid contact with wild birds or their excrement, and to call the INPA on *3639 if they see any signs of sick or dead birds.

[Byline: Sue Surkes]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MENA
via
ProMED

******
[3] Table egg supply, public health concerns
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Poultrymed [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited]
<https://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=2&TMID=178&FID=14756&PID=0&IID=43398>


The Haaretz daily published today [Sun 26 Dec 2021] a headline announcing apprehension that eggs from birds infected with bird flu had reached IDF [Israel's army] bases. As is well known, the [named] farm in Moshav Margaliot supplies the IDF with eggs from its laying farms. The outbreak of bird flu in Moshav Margaliot spread from the center of the moshav [cooperative village] to the egg-laying enterprise of the said firm next to the moshav, and now it is feared that eggs from an infected farm have reached the table of IDF soldiers.

Avian influenza viruses, defined as pathogenic, can contaminate the contents of the egg in addition to external contamination of the shell. Therefore, these eggs have the potential for spreading infection (scientific references at the URL).

At the same time, it is reported that the Ministry of Agriculture has approved egg imports (14 million) for fear of shortage. Of note, this import measure was approved even before the outbreak of bird flu in Moshav Margaliot. The Poultry Industry Council recommends approving imports amounting to 70 million eggs.

There aren't many import options since most European countries are also infected with bird flu (except Spain), including Ukraine (early December 2021, outbreak in a poultry farm in the Kherson oblast).

[The report includes 4 citations which are available at the source URL].

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MENA
via
ProMED

[According to an update in Poultrymed, 26 Dec 2021, 2 additional HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in poultry (turkey farms) have recently been identified by the State Veterinary Services. One, in Ein-Hachoresh, central Israel (19-week-old turkeys); the other one, in the Givat Yoav moshav, on the Golan Heights. This outbreak is situated about 2 km [1.2 mi] as the crow flies from an earlier outbreak, reported last week in Neot Golan, which similarly kept 13.6-week-old turkeys. Both are about 35km [21.7mi] distant, on their north northeast, from the Hula Lake reserve (crane outbreak) and 48km [29.8mi] from Margaliot (map at <tinyurl.com/2e2z6phj>).

The epidemiological aspects of this unusual event are yet to be studied in depth, preferably incorporating animal health, public health, environmental, ornithology, and farming experts. Among the issues to be investigated is the route of the pathogen's initial introduction to the region, its timeline, in particular poultry-infecting-wildlife or vice versa route(s), and the impact of wildlife (feeding) and poultry (small, numerous, dense coops) managements upon the disastrous disease/mortality both in cranes and on farms, respectively. The conclusions and recommendations of such inquiry are of significance, not only for the farming industry and environmentalists but for the public at large.

Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 panzootic, in September 2021, vast regions in Europe and Asia have been affected; fortunately, not a single human case has, so far, been reported. - Mod.AS]

[Detailed information about avian and other zoonotic influenza can be found at <http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/avian_influenza/en/>. - Mod.SMA]

Date: Mon 27 Dec 2021 22:20 KST
Source: Yonhap News Agency [edited]
<https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20211227007900325>


South Korea on Monday [27 Dec 2021] reported another suspected case of highly pathogenic avian influenza at a duck farm in a southwestern county, the agriculture ministry said.

The latest case was reported at the farm raising about 10 000 ducks in Busan, 280 km [173.9 mi] south of Seoul, according to the ministry.

There are no poultry farms within 1 km [0.6 mi] of the farm in question. Health authorities have cordoned off the site and taken other precautionary measures to prevent the potential spread of the disease outside the farm, the authorities said.

Highly pathogenic avian influenza is very contagious among birds and can cause severe illness and even death, especially in domestic poultry. The country has been reporting a slew of bird flu cases since November this year [2021].

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MBDS

[The newswire above provides no detailed information on the avian influenza subtype.

"On 20 Dec 2021, avian influenza outbreak was reported at a farm where around 12 000 ducks are being raised in Yeongam, 384 km [238 mi] south of Seoul, according to the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs. Health authorities have cordoned off the site and are culling ducks there to prevent the spread of the disease outside the farm, it added."
(see ProMED-MBDS archive 20211220.8700394 and https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20211220008300325)

"Busan officially known as Busan Metropolitan City, is South Korea's 2nd most populous city after Seoul, with a population of over 3.4 million inhabitants. The surrounding "Southeast Economic Zone" (including Ulsan and South Gyeongsang) is South Korea's largest industrial area."
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Busan>)
- Mod.TTM

Date: Mon 27 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=45054>


Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (Inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Canada
------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 9 Dec 2021
Confirmed: 20 Dec 2021
Reported: 22 Dec 2021
Reason for notification: recurrence
Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus
Serotype: H5N1
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

New outbreaks
Total outbreaks (1)
Outbreak location: Avalon Peninsula, St John's Division No 1, Newfoundland and Labrador
Started: 9 Dec 2021
Epidemiological unit: farm
Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 419 / 360 / 360 / 59 / - / -

Affected population: The site is an exhibition farm with multiple bird species (chicken, turkeys, emus, geese, ducks, guinea fowl and peafowl) as well as multiple mammalian species. The geographic coordinates do not represent the actual location of the premises.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive, contact with wild bird.

Epidemiological comments: The infected premises is an exhibition farm located on an island off the Atlantic coast of Canada. A protection zone (3km) [about 1.86mi] and a surveillance zone (10 km) [about 6.2mi] have been put in place around the infected premises. The virus has HA cleavage site motif "PLREKRRK/GLF" consistent with highly pathogenic avian influenza strains of H5 subtype. The HA gene segment is A/goose/Guangdong/1996 (Gs/GD) lineage belonging to 2.3.4.4B clade. Phylogenic analysis indicates this virus corresponds to the Eurasian lineage circulating in 2021. Wildlife surveillance as well as the Canadian Avian Influenza Surveillance System (CanNAISS) activities for poultry are ongoing in Canada. According to article 10.4.1.4 of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code, member countries should not impose bans on the international trade of poultry commodities in response to notification of infection with any Influenza A viruses in birds other than poultry.

Control measures applied in domestic: traceability; stamping out; quarantine; zoning; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone

Control measures to be applied in domestic: disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste

Control measures applied in wild: surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Outbreaks / Test date / Result
Atlantic Veterinary College Diagnostic Services (Local Laboratory)/ Birds / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 1 / 16 Dec 2021 / Positive
National Centre for Foreign Animal Disease (NCFAD), Winnipeg, Manitoba National Laboratory / Birds / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 1 / 19 Dec 2021 / Positive
National Centre for Foreign Animal Disease (NCFAD), Winnipeg, Manitoba National Laboratory / Birds / gene sequencing / 1 / 20 Dec 2021 / Positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[This official report sent to the OIE, complements the information already published in ProMED post 20211225.8700481.

"The infected birds were located on an exhibition farm; the detection is considered a non-poultry detection according to the OIE definition. Canada's animal health status as 'free from AI' remains in place. No trade restrictions are anticipated as a result of this detection". Source: Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) <https://inspection.canada.ca/animal-health/terrestrial-animals/diseases/reportable/avian-influenza/statement/eng/1640207916497/1640207916934> (22 Dec 2021).

According to the OIE Terrestrial Code, the definition of poultry, "means all birds reared or kept in captivity for the production of any commercial animal products or for breeding for this purpose, fighting cocks used for any purpose, and all birds used for restocking supplies of game or for breeding for this purpose, until they are released from captivity.

"Birds that are kept in a single household, the products of which are used within the same household exclusively, are not considered poultry, provided that they have no direct or indirect contact with poultry or poultry facilities.

"Birds that are kept in captivity for other reasons, including those that are kept for shows, racing, exhibitions, zoological collections and competitions, and for breeding or selling for these purposes, as well as pet birds, are not considered poultry, provided that they have no direct or indirect contact with poultry or poultry facilities". Source: OIE Terrestrial Code 2021, Glossary section (<https://www.oie.int/en/what-we-do/standards/codes-and-manuals/terrestrial-code-online-access/?id=169&L=1&htmfile=glossaire.htm>). - Mod.CRD

content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (183): ISRAEL (HAZAFON) POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD
*****************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Poultry, wild birds
[2] Cranes, mass mortality, Hula Lake Reserve
[3] Table egg supply, public health concerns

******
[1] Poultry, wild birds
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Spiegel via The Limited Times [edited]
<https://newsrnd.com/tech/2021-12-26-avian-flu-is-spreading-in-israel--affecting-migratory-birds.SkDo2WLjt.html>


Israel is fighting the spread of bird flu.

A spokeswoman for the Israeli Ministry of Agriculture confirmed that there was an outbreak in battery cages near the village of Margaliot in the north of the country on the border with Lebanon.

320 000 laying hens would therefore have to be killed, in addition to 244 000 hens that had already been killed a week ago.

Mass deaths had also previously been observed in other laying batteries in Israel.

"The Ministry of Agriculture is concerned that people could be infected by infected battery cells near homes," said a statement.

It is now expected that there will be a shortage of eggs on the Israeli market -- around 14 million eggs are missing every month due to bird flu.

The outbreak in Israel could have consequences for other regions.

According to media reports, about 20% of the cranes that come to Israel as migrating birds from southern Europe to stop there on their way to Africa are also affected by the disease.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED 

******
[2] Cranes, mass mortality, Hula Lake Reserve
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Times of Israel [edited]
<https://www.timesofisrael.com/5000-dead-cranes-counted-at-hula-lake-reserve-amidst-bird-flu-outbreak/>


Some 5000 dead cranes were counted Sunday [26 Dec 2021] at the Hula Lake Reserve in northern Israel, amid an outbreak of avian flu that has also seen the culling of more than half a million chickens and turkeys.

The Hula Lake is the main gathering point for tens of thousands of wild birds that migrate through Israel twice yearly.

Nature authorities provide food there, to keep the birds away from farmers' crops.

Feeding is continuing since the outbreak of the H5N1 virus at the lake, and in chicken sheds at Moshav Margaliot on the Lebanese border, to try to keep the cranes from flying elsewhere and taking the virus with them.

During a tour of the area on Sunday [26 Dec 2021] by staff of the Israel Nature and Parks Authority [INPA] and KKL-JNF Jewish National Fund, accompanied by Environmental Protection Minister Tamar Zandberg, another 250 dead cranes were seen in the Hula Valley outside of the reserve, and a further 30 were documented elsewhere, mainly in the Jezreel Valley.

A pelican with bird flu was reported in the Hefer Valley in central Israel and samples were being taken from dead birds at Kfar Ruppin in the Beit She'an Valley.

The INPA believes that the disease spread from Moshav Margaliot, via a truck driver who delivered food to the chicken coops there and then brought food to the Hula Reserve. A spokeswoman said there had never been such an avian flu outbreak among wild birds.

The Agriculture Ministry has said that the farmers on the moshav failed to report the outbreak in real time, allowing it to spread like wildfire.

The Hula Reserve will remain closed to the public until [1 Jan 2021].

Members of the public are advised to cook eggs and poultry meat thoroughly before eating, to avoid contact with wild birds or their excrement, and to call the INPA on *3639 if they see any signs of sick or dead birds.

[Byline: Sue Surkes]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[3] Table egg supply, public health concerns
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Poultrymed [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited] 
<https://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=2&TMID=178&FID=14756&PID=0&IID=43398>


The Haaretz daily published today (26 Dec 2021) a headline announcing apprehension that eggs from birds infected with bird flu had reached IDF [Israel's army] bases. As is well known, the [named] farm in Moshav Margaliot supplies the IDF with eggs from its laying farms. The outbreak of bird flu in Moshav Margaliot spread from the center of the moshav [cooperative village] to the egg-laying enterprise of the said firm next to the moshav, and now it is feared that eggs from an infected farm have reached the table of IDF soldiers.

What is the risk?
Avian influenza viruses, defined as pathogenic, can contaminate the contents of the egg in addition to external contamination of the shell. Therefore, these eggs have the potential for spreading infection (scientific references attached). 

At the same time, it is reported that the Ministry of Agriculture has approved egg imports (14 million) for fear of shortage. It must be noted that this import measure was approved even before the outbreak of bird flu in Moshav Margaliot. The Poultry Industry Council recommends approving imports amounting to 70 million eggs.

There aren't many import options since most European countries are also infected with bird flu (except Spain), including Ukraine (early December 2021, outbreak in a poultry farm in the Kherson oblast).

[The report includes 4 citations which are available at the source URL]. 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED 

[According to an update in Poultrymed, 26 Dec 2021, 2 additional HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in poultry (turkey farms) have recently been identified by the State Veterinary Services. One, in Ein-Hachoresh, central Israel (19-week-old turkeys); the other one, in the Givat Yoav moshav, on the Golan Heights. This outbreak is situated about 2 km [1.2 mi] as the crow flies from an earlier outbreak, reported last week in Neot Golan, which similarly kept 13.6-week-old turkeys. Both are about 35 km [21.7 mi] distant, on their north northeast, from the Hula Lake reserve (crane outbreak) and 48 km [29.8 km] from Margaliot (map at <tinyurl.com/2e2z6phj>). 

The epidemiological aspects of this unusual event are yet to be studied at depth, preferably incorporating animal health, public health, environmental, ornithology and farming experts. Among the issues to be investigated are the route of the pathogen's initial introduction to the region, its timeline, in particular poultry-infecting-wildlife or vice versa route(s), and the impact of wildlife (feeding) and poultry (small, numerous, dense coops) managements upon the disastrous disease/mortality both in cranes and on farms, respectively. The conclusions and recommendations of such inquiry are of significance, not only for the farming industry and environmentalists but for the public at large. 

Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 panzootic, in September 2021, vast regions in Europe and Asia have been affected; fortunately, not a single human case has, so far, been reported. - Mod.AS

Israel: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700508,90>]

content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (183): ISRAEL (HAZAFON) POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD
*****************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Poultry, wild birds
[2] Cranes, mass mortality, Hula Lake Reserve
[3] Table egg supply, public health concerns

******
[1] Poultry, wild birds
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Spiegel via The Limited Times [edited]
<https://newsrnd.com/tech/2021-12-26-avian-flu-is-spreading-in-israel--affecting-migratory-birds.SkDo2WLjt.html>


Israel is fighting the spread of bird flu.

A spokeswoman for the Israeli Ministry of Agriculture confirmed that there was an outbreak in battery cages near the village of Margaliot in the north of the country on the border with Lebanon.

320 000 laying hens would therefore have to be killed, in addition to 244 000 hens that had already been killed a week ago.

Mass deaths had also previously been observed in other laying batteries in Israel.

"The Ministry of Agriculture is concerned that people could be infected by infected battery cells near homes," said a statement.

It is now expected that there will be a shortage of eggs on the Israeli market -- around 14 million eggs are missing every month due to bird flu.

The outbreak in Israel could have consequences for other regions.

According to media reports, about 20% of the cranes that come to Israel as migrating birds from southern Europe to stop there on their way to Africa are also affected by the disease.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED 

******
[2] Cranes, mass mortality, Hula Lake Reserve
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Times of Israel [edited]
<https://www.timesofisrael.com/5000-dead-cranes-counted-at-hula-lake-reserve-amidst-bird-flu-outbreak/>


Some 5000 dead cranes were counted Sunday [26 Dec 2021] at the Hula Lake Reserve in northern Israel, amid an outbreak of avian flu that has also seen the culling of more than half a million chickens and turkeys.

The Hula Lake is the main gathering point for tens of thousands of wild birds that migrate through Israel twice yearly.

Nature authorities provide food there, to keep the birds away from farmers' crops.

Feeding is continuing since the outbreak of the H5N1 virus at the lake, and in chicken sheds at Moshav Margaliot on the Lebanese border, to try to keep the cranes from flying elsewhere and taking the virus with them.

During a tour of the area on Sunday [26 Dec 2021] by staff of the Israel Nature and Parks Authority [INPA] and KKL-JNF Jewish National Fund, accompanied by Environmental Protection Minister Tamar Zandberg, another 250 dead cranes were seen in the Hula Valley outside of the reserve, and a further 30 were documented elsewhere, mainly in the Jezreel Valley.

A pelican with bird flu was reported in the Hefer Valley in central Israel and samples were being taken from dead birds at Kfar Ruppin in the Beit She'an Valley.

The INPA believes that the disease spread from Moshav Margaliot, via a truck driver who delivered food to the chicken coops there and then brought food to the Hula Reserve. A spokeswoman said there had never been such an avian flu outbreak among wild birds.

The Agriculture Ministry has said that the farmers on the moshav failed to report the outbreak in real time, allowing it to spread like wildfire.

The Hula Reserve will remain closed to the public until [1 Jan 2021].

Members of the public are advised to cook eggs and poultry meat thoroughly before eating, to avoid contact with wild birds or their excrement, and to call the INPA on *3639 if they see any signs of sick or dead birds.

[Byline: Sue Surkes]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[3] Table egg supply, public health concerns
Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: Poultrymed [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited] 
<https://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=2&TMID=178&FID=14756&PID=0&IID=43398>


The Haaretz daily published today (26 Dec 2021) a headline announcing apprehension that eggs from birds infected with bird flu had reached IDF [Israel's army] bases. As is well known, the [named] farm in Moshav Margaliot supplies the IDF with eggs from its laying farms. The outbreak of bird flu in Moshav Margaliot spread from the center of the moshav [cooperative village] to the egg-laying enterprise of the said firm next to the moshav, and now it is feared that eggs from an infected farm have reached the table of IDF soldiers.

What is the risk?
Avian influenza viruses, defined as pathogenic, can contaminate the contents of the egg in addition to external contamination of the shell. Therefore, these eggs have the potential for spreading infection (scientific references attached). 

At the same time, it is reported that the Ministry of Agriculture has approved egg imports (14 million) for fear of shortage. It must be noted that this import measure was approved even before the outbreak of bird flu in Moshav Margaliot. The Poultry Industry Council recommends approving imports amounting to 70 million eggs.

There aren't many import options since most European countries are also infected with bird flu (except Spain), including Ukraine (early December 2021, outbreak in a poultry farm in the Kherson oblast).

[The report includes 4 citations which are available at the source URL]. 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED 

[According to an update in Poultrymed, 26 Dec 2021, 2 additional HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in poultry (turkey farms) have recently been identified by the State Veterinary Services. One, in Ein-Hachoresh, central Israel (19-week-old turkeys); the other one, in the Givat Yoav moshav, on the Golan Heights. This outbreak is situated about 2 km [1.2 mi] as the crow flies from an earlier outbreak, reported last week in Neot Golan, which similarly kept 13.6-week-old turkeys. Both are about 35 km [21.7 mi] distant, on their north northeast, from the Hula Lake reserve (crane outbreak) and 48 km [29.8 km] from Margaliot (map at <tinyurl.com/2e2z6phj>). 

The epidemiological aspects of this unusual event are yet to be studied at depth, preferably incorporating animal health, public health, environmental, ornithology and farming experts. Among the issues to be investigated are the route of the pathogen's initial introduction to the region, its timeline, in particular poultry-infecting-wildlife or vice versa route(s), and the impact of wildlife (feeding) and poultry (small, numerous, dense coops) managements upon the disastrous disease/mortality both in cranes and on farms, respectively. The conclusions and recommendations of such inquiry are of significance, not only for the farming industry and environmentalists but for the public at large. 

Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 panzootic, in September 2021, vast regions in Europe and Asia have been affected; fortunately, not a single human case has, so far, been reported. - Mod.AS

ProMED map:
Israel: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700508,90>]

summary: PRO/RUS> Зарубежное эпизоотическое обозрение - высокопатогенный грипп птиц H5N1- Великобритания (2), Израиль (3)
content:
Зарубежное эпизоотическое обозрение - высокопатогенный грипп птиц H5N1- Великобритания (2), Израиль (3)
**************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Дата: 26 декабря 2021 года
 
(1)
Источник: Казах Зерно, 26 декабря 2021 года
<https://kazakh-zerno.net/189668-velikobritanija-perezhivaet-samuju-krupnuju-v-istorii-vspyshku-ptichego-grippa/?utm_source>
 
Великобритания переживает самую крупную в истории вспышку птичьего гриппа
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Джордж Юстис, министр сельского хозяйства и окружающей среды Англии, сделал заявление, выступая в Парламенте. По его словам, в 2021 г. страна переживает крупнейшую в историю вспышку птичьего гриппа. На сегодняшний день подтвердили путем проведения лабораторных анализов тридцать шесть вспышек в разных регионах государства. Эксперты связывают их с сезонный риском, который связан с перемещениями переплётных диких птиц.
Кристин Миддлмисс, главный ветеринар Великобритании, объявила о выбраковке около 2 млн. голов птицы из-за обнаружения у них высокопатогенного птичьего гриппа H5N1. Впервые вирус выявили в спасательном центре в Вустершире (27 октября 2021 г.). С тех пор он уже добрался до разных областей Южного Саффолка и Северного Йоркшира. В птичниках, в которых обнаруживают заражённую птицу, проводят полную выбраковку поголовья.
3 ноября в стране объявили общенациональную зону предотвращения птичьего грипп. Фермы и птицеводы должны ужесточить меры биологической защиты. Спустя двадцать шесть дней зону расширили, включив в нее еще и меры по содержанию птиц. Кроме того, от британских птицеводов требуют содержать птицу в закрытых помещениях.
Не только одна Англия страдает от вспышек птичьего гриппа. В последние несколько недель он быстро распространяется по Европе, добрался до Дании, Голландии, Италии, Германии и Франции.
 
(2)
Источник: Наше кафе, 26 декабря 2021 года
<https://nashe.orbita.co.il/post/view?id=108363&utm_source=yxnews&utm_medium=desktop>
 
Эпидемия куриного гриппа: в Израиле будет ощущаться острый дефицит яиц
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Эпидемия опасного вирусного заболевания домашней птицы (куриный грипп H5N1 – прим. НК), которая распространяется на Севере Израиля, может уже на этой неделе привести к острому дефициту куриных яиц.
По данным 12 канала ИТВ, на территории поселения Маргалийот (Голанские высоты), которое является одним из центров по производству куриного мяса и яиц, были изолированы несколько крупных курятников/
По прогнозам специалистов, более 600.000 несущих кур должны быть умерщвлены в сжатые сроки с тем, чтобы ограничить распространение опасного заболевания.
По данным Минсельхоза, в ближайшее время в Израиле обнаружится дефицит в 14 млн куриных яиц.
По сообщению Минздрава Израиля, в медицинском ведомстве опасаться, что эпидемия куриного гриппа может возникнуть и среди жителей Маргалийот, где курятники прилегают к домам.
--
Communicated by:
ProMED-RUS
<promed-rus@promedmail.org>
 
 
 

 



[Комментарий Корр. ЛЕ. Европейское управление по безопасности пищевых продуктов (EFSA) и Европейский центр по контролю за заболеваниями (ECDC) оценивают зоонозный риск высокопатогенного птичьего гриппа (HPAI) как более высокий, чем это было до сих пор. Для людей, которые профессионально контактируют с домашней птицей, риск увеличивается с «низкого» до «низкого или среднего». В отчете EFSA и ECDC представлен обзор текущей ситуации с птичьим гриппом в Европе. В отчете даются всевозможные рекомендации по предотвращению вспышки зооноза, вызванного птичьим гриппом. Так, в Нидерландах практически все необходимые меры уже применяются. В письме в парламент министры обсуждают обнаружение в начале этого месяца лисы в Дорсте в Брабанте, зараженной вирусом птичьего гриппа. В найденной мертвой лисице обнаружен вирус птичьего гриппа H5N1 <https://rossaprimavera.ru/news/f9a44db5>
По данным ProMED, в текущем году в Китае,  было зарегистрировано 7 случаев птичьего гриппа у людей, из которых как минимум 2 завершились летальным исходом.
Всякий раз, когда вирусы птичьего гриппа циркулируют среди домашней птицы, существует риск спорадической инфекции и небольших групп случаев заболевания людей, тесно контактировавших с инфицированной домашней птицей. Ранее ProMED сообщал также о случаях высокопатогенного гриппа птиц H5N8 у людей в Бельгии и Люксембурге.
Случаи инфицирования человека вирусом гриппа птиц A(H5N8) в феврале 2021 года <Archive Number: 20210220.8203966> выявили в России. Инфекция была выявлена у семерых сотрудников птицефабрики в Астраханской области <Archive Number: 20210221.8204665>, где в декабре 2020 года среди поголовья птиц зарегистрировали вспышку гриппа птиц. Болезнь протекала в легкой форме.
Кластер случаев заражения человека возбудителем высокопатогенного гриппа птиц впервые зарегистрировали в Гонконге в 1997 во время вспышки гриппа у домашней птицы, когда заболело 18 человек, 6 умерли. Был выявлен подтип вируса — H5N1, установлено, что вирус передавался от птиц человеку. По данным Всемирной организации здравоохранения, c 2003 по 2021 год из 863 подтвержденных случаев заражения людей вирусом птичьего гриппа H5N1 456 стали смертельными. По данным ProMED <Archive Number: 20210721.8535694>, в июле в Индии в результате инфекции данным штаммом погиб 11-летний ребенок. Пандемии гриппа, вызванные новыми подтипами вирусов гриппа (или штаммами как в случае с вирусом гриппа А (H1N1)pdm2009, против которых у людей нет иммунитета, возникают обычно 2—3 раза в 100 лет. - Corr. LE]

[See Also:
Смотрите также:
20 Dec 2021 Зарубежное эпизоотическое обозрение - высокопатогенный грипп птиц - Южная Корея, Дания, Болгария  20211220.8700402]
.................................................le/np

Ранее ProMED сообщал также о случаях высокопатогенного гриппа птиц H5N8 у людей в Бельгии и Люксембурге.
Случаи инфицирования человека вирусом гриппа птиц A(H5N8) в феврале 2021 года <Archive Number: 20210220.8203966> выявили в России. Инфекция была выявлена у семерых сотрудников птицефабрики в Астраханской области <Archive Number: 20210221.8204665>, где в декабре 2020 года среди поголовья птиц зарегистрировали вспышку гриппа птиц. Болезнь протекала в легкой форме.
Кластер случаев заражения человека возбудителем высокопатогенного гриппа птиц впервые зарегистрировали в Гонконге в 1997 во время вспышки гриппа у домашней птицы, когда заболело 18 человек, 6 умерли. Был выявлен подтип вируса — H5N1, установлено, что вирус передавался от птиц человеку. По данным Всемирной организации здравоохранения, c 2003 по 2021 год из 863 подтвержденных случаев заражения людей вирусом птичьего гриппа H5N1 456 стали смертельными. По данным ProMED <Archive Number: 20210721.8535694>, в июле в Индии в результате инфекции данным штаммом погиб 11-летний ребенок. Пандемии гриппа, вызванные новыми подтипами вирусов гриппа (или штаммами как в случае с вирусом гриппа А (H1N1)pdm2009, против которых у людей нет иммунитета, возникают обычно 2—3 раза в 100 лет. - Corr. LE]

AVIAN INFLUENZA (182): EUROPE (PORTUGAL) POULTRY, SPREAD
********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 26 Dec 2021
Source: CM [in Portuguese, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.cmjornal.pt/sociedade/detalhe/perus-com-gripe-das-aves-abatidos-em-obidos>


An outbreak of bird flu was detected in a farm with thousands of turkeys in Avarela, Obidos. The General Directorate of Food and Veterinary Medicine (DGAV) has already activated a contingency plan, establishing, among others, the slaughter of affected animals and a sanitary restriction around the affected area, within a radius of up to 10 kilometers [6.2 mi]. At issue is a "highly pathogenic avian flu", with very high mortality rates, and which can infect other animals and also humans, when there is very close contact.

However, DGAV stresses that "there is no epidemiological evidence of avian influenza transmission to humans through food consumption, namely poultry meat and eggs".

To prevent the spread of the disease, a protection zone and a surveillance zone were defined, covering respectively 3 and 10 kilometer radii around the poultry farm. The DGAV banned the circulation of live birds in the restriction area, but also that of fresh meat, including offal and poultry meat products. The same applies to the circulation of eggs for hatching and for human consumption, as well as animal by-products obtained from birds originating from production in the affected area.

The contingency plan provides for the elimination of infected birds, with compensation being made for the sanitary slaughter of the animals. The measures apply until 27 Jan 2022, and poultry farms in this zone will be subject to inspection.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED 

[The previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak of the current season, in Portugal, started on 30 Nov 2021 and was reported to the OIE on 6 Dec 2021 (item 3 in ProMED post 20211209.8700162). It affected a backyard hobby flock of chickens, ducks, turkeys and geese located in the province of Setubal (map at <https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43980>). The current event is located in the district of Leiria. Both areas are situated in western Portugal, respectively south and north of the Lisbon district (map at <https://www.mappr.co/counties/portugal/>). 

The current epizootic of HPAI H5N1 has spread, since its start (September 2021), throughout most parts of Europe, in several countries in Asia and, to a lesser extent, Africa. Most likely, by means of migrating birds. 

So far, no human cases have been reported. - Mod.AS

AVIAN INFLUENZA (181): CANADA (NEWFOUNDLAND AND LABRADOR) H5N1, POULTRY
***********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Thu 23 Dec 2021
Source: VOCM [edited]
<https://vocm.com/2021/12/23/canadian-food-inspection-agency-confirms-presence-of-avian-flu-at-avalon-peninsula-exhibition-farm/>


The Canadian Food Inspection Agency [CFIA] has confirmed the presence of what it's calling a high pathogenic [HP] Avian Influenza [AI], subtype H5N1, at an exhibition farm on the Avalon Peninsula.
 
The farm does not produce birds for sale.
 
The federal agency says the provincial department and the owner are working with CFIA to manage the situation.
 
The infected birds were located on the farm, which contains a variety of other species of animals. No other cases resembling Avian Flu have been reported in the vicinity of the farm.
 
The CFIA says Avian Flu circulates naturally in birds and recent detections of high pathogenic AI in Europe indicate an even higher risk of the disease in North American poultry this year [2021].
 
The federal agency says it is important anyone raising poultry remain vigilant against AI and ensure they have effective biosecurity measures in place.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2]
Date: Thu 23 Dec 2021
Source: OFFLU [edited]
<https://www.offlu.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/OFFLU-statement_Newfoundland__H5N1.pdf>


OFFLU statement on outbreak of H5N1 high pathogenicity avian influenza in Newfoundland, Canada
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The recent detection of an H5N1 high pathogenicity avian influenza (HPAI) virus in Newfoundland, Canada represents the first identification of goose/Guangdong/1/96-lineage (Gs/GD/96) H5 HPAI virus in the Americas since June 2015. This is cause for concern for wild birds, zoological collections, and poultry in the Americas(1). Some east coast states of the United States of America (USA) are home to very large poultry populations that could be at risk of exposure and outbreaks in the next few months. This finding raises concerns about the potential of this virus becoming established in the Americas within migratory and resident birds.

Epidemiological information on the HPAI outbreak is limited. It involved an exhibition farm in St John's on the Avalon Peninsula and resulted in the death of 360 of 409 mixed species of birds (layers, geese, ducks, silkie hens, peafowl, turkeys) kept on the farm. Full genome sequence of the virus was obtained from 9 clinical samples collected from the infected premises. Based on BLAST analysis all 8 gene segments of the virus are of Eurasian origin. The virus has been confirmed as a clade 2.3.4.4b H5N1 virus, phylogenetically all 8 gene segments of the virus are related to 2.3.4.4b clade H5N1 virus currently circulating widely in wild birds and poultry in Europe. The outbreak commenced on 9 Dec 2021. This is the first time that a clade 2.3.4.4b virus within the goose/Guangdong/1/96-lineage (Gs/GD/96) has been detected in the Americas. The remaining birds in the farm were depopulated and the Canadian authorities are continuing investigations, including additional testing of wild birds and poultry in the area.

High pathogenicity Gs/GD/96-lineage H5 virus was last introduced to North America in late 2014 and caused the largest animal health emergency in the USA during 2015. That virus arrived from Asia across the Bering Strait, belonged to clade 2.3.4.4c, and, initially, affected birds on the west coast of Canada and the USA. The current Newfoundland outbreak represents a new introduction of a different, but phylogenetically related, high pathogenicity virus. This virus lineage has shown to be capable of being carried over long distances by migratory birds, based on experiences from Eurasia and Africa.

It has been recognised for some time that, although avian influenza viruses tend to be classified into North American and Eurasian lineages, viral genes and, on occasions, whole viruses can cross the Atlantic divide (Dusek et al., 2014). The introduction of a Gs/GD/96-lineage H5 HPAI via this route was considered possible previously (Sims et al., 2017). We postulate that a wild bird introduction might have occurred in the current outbreak (direct or indirect), although other pathways cannot be ruled out. If this is the result of wild bird introduction, experiences from Eurasia suggest that rapid and wide dispersal of the virus could occur. There are few poultry in the Maritime provinces of Canada, which means there is a limited population of susceptible poultry that could provide a warning of wider transmission of the virus by wild birds.

We urge all countries in the Americas and Caribbean to increase surveillance of wild birds and poultry for any evidence of infection with this virus, and, also, advise poultry producers and keepers of other types of birds to implement stricter biosecurity measures until more information becomes available.

References:
Dusek RJ, Hallgrimsson GT, Ip HS, Jónsson JE, Sreevatsan S, Nashold SW, TeSlaa JL, Enomoto

S, Halpin RA, Lin X, Fedorova N, Stockwell TB, Dugan VG, Wentworth DE, Hall JS. North Atlantic migratory bird flyways provide routes for intercontinental movement of avian influenza viruses. PLoS One. 2014 Mar 19;9(3):e92075. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0092075. PMID: 24647410; PMCID: PMC3960164.

Sims L, Harder T, Brown I, Gaidet N, Belot G, von Dobschuetz S, Kamata A, Kivaria F, Palamara E, Bruni M, Dauphin G, Raizman E, Lubroth J 2017. Highly pathogenic H5 avian influenza in 2016 and 2017 - observations and future perspectives. FOCUS ON, No. 11, Nov 2017. Rome

(1) See <https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=45054> and <https://inspection.canada.ca/animal-health/terrestrial-animals/diseases/reportable/avian-influenza/statement/eng/1640207916497/1640207916934>

--
Communicated by:
Ian Brown
<ian.brown@apha.gov.uk>

[Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) is a serious situation.

"AI viruses are classified by a combination of 2 groups of proteins: the hemagglutinin or H proteins, of which there are 16 (H1-H16), and neuraminidase or N proteins, of which there are 9 (N1-N9). Many strains of avian influenza (AI) virus exist worldwide. These viruses affect chickens, turkeys, pheasants, quail, ducks, geese, and guinea fowl as well as a wide variety of free-flying species. Migratory waterfowl have been shown to be a natural reservoir for AI. AI strains also are divided into 2 groups based upon the ability of the virus to produce disease. 

"Low Pathogenicity or "low path" Avian Influenza (LPAI)
LPAI occurs naturally in wild birds and can spread to domestic birds. In most cases it causes no signs of infection or only minor symptoms in birds. These strains of the disease pose little significant threat to human health. These strains are common in the U.S. and around the world.

"Highly Pathogenicity or "high path" Avian Influenza (HPAI) 
HPAI is often fatal in chickens and turkeys. HPAI spreads rapidly and has a higher death rate in birds than LPAI. HPAI has been detected and eradicated 3 times in U.S. domestic poultry. HPAI H5N1 is the subtype rapidly spreading in some parts of the world. Most of the highly pathogenic AI viruses fall under types H5 or H7; however, most AI infections, including those typed as H5 or H7, are clinically of low pathogenicity. These typically produce few or no clinical signs in affected birds. Sometimes the only evidence of this virus is a minor increase in bird mortality. Aside from the possible mutation of low-pathogenicity strains under field conditions into high-pathogenicity strains, the presence of low-pathogenicity virus can also result in restrictions on exports and serious repercussions on the production economy. Avian Influenza of H5 and H7 subtypes are known as Notifiable Avian Influenza (NAI). APHIS works to keep NAI from becoming established in U.S. poultry populations. 

"Identifying Infected Birds
Birds infected with the HPAI virus may show one or more of the following signs:
•	Sudden death without clinical signs;
•	Lack of energy and appetite;
•	Decreased egg production or soft-shelled or misshapen eggs;
•	Swelling of head, comb, eyelid, wattles, and hocks;
•	Purple discoloration of wattles, comb, and legs;
•	Nasal discharge, coughing, and sneezing;
•	Incoordination; or
•	Diarrhea. 

"Epidemiology
HPAI can strike poultry quickly and spread rapidly from premises to premises. Migratory waterfowl can introduce the disease to U.S. poultry. International visitors or smuggled birds are also risk factors. Once introduced, the disease spreads from bird to bird by direct contact or through contact with contaminated manure, equipment, vehicles, crates, and the clothing or shoes of individuals who have come in contact with the virus. The virus remains viable in the environment for long periods, particularly at lower temperatures, and it can survive indefinitely in frozen material. 

"Biosecurity Measures on the Farm
Veterinarians should work with poultry producers to strengthen biosecurity practices. Established and enforced biosecurity protocols will help prevent introduction of HPAI and other infectious agents. Recommended biosecurity measures include
•	Establishing an "all-in, all-out" flock-management policy;
•	Protecting against exposure to wild birds or water or ground contaminated by wild birds;
•	Closing bird areas to nonessential personnel or vehicles; 
•	Providing employees with clean clothing and disinfection facilities and directions for their use;
•	Thoroughly cleaning and disinfecting equipment and vehicles (including tires and undercarriage) when entering or leaving the farm;
•	Banning the borrowing or lending of equipment or vehicles;
•	Banning visits to other poultry farms, exhibitions, fairs, and sales or swap meets (if visits must occur, direct workers to change footwear and clothing on their return); and
•	Banning bringing birds in slaughter channels back to the farm. 

"Reporting Suspicious Diseases
Practitioners are encouraged to educate their poultry clientele and pet bird owners to report all signs of disease. If signs of disease resemble AI or cannot be diagnosed, they should immediately be reported to both the Assistant District Director and the State Animal Health Official."
Extracted from: <https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/nvap/NVAP-Reference-Guide/Poultry/Avian-Influenza>. - Mod.TG

Black-faced spoonbill (_Platalea minor_): Threskiornithidae-Phaethontiformes / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0
Affected population: a dead, black-faced spoonbill was collected on [16 Dec 2021] at the mudflat of Hong Kong Wetland Park. The species is a common winter visitor in Deep Bay areas with a small number recorded in summer.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: an intensive surveillance system is in place for all poultry farms, poultry markets, and pet bird shops in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected bird was detected in the ongoing territory wide surveillance program on wild birds. No spread of the disease was evident. There are 2 poultry farms located within 3 kilometers [2 mi] of where the bird was found. No abnormalities or signs of avian influenza were found in the 2 farms. The end date of the outbreak is the same as the date the bird was found (16 Dec 2021).

Control measures applied [in wild]: disinfection; screening

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result
Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture Fisheries and Conservation Department National Laboratory / black-faced spoonbill / virus isolation / 20 Dec 2021 / positive
Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture Fisheries and Conservation Department National Laboratory / black-faced spoonbill / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 17 Dec 2021 / positive
Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture Fisheries and Conservation Department National Laboratory / black-faced spoonbill / direct rapid immunohistochemical test / 17 Dec 2021 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MBDS

["From January 2004 through June 2008, surveillance of dead wild birds in Hong Kong, People's Republic of China, periodically detected highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) viruses (H5N1) in individual birds from different species. During this period, no viruses of subtype H5N1 were detected in poultry on farms and in markets in Hong Kong despite intensive surveillance. Thus, these findings in wild birds demonstrate the potential for wild birds to disseminate HPAI viruses (H5N1) to areas otherwise free from the viruses. Genetic and antigenic characterization of 47 HPAI (H5N1) viruses isolated from dead wild birds in Hong Kong showed that these isolates belonged to 2 antigenically distinct virus groups: clades 2.3.4 and 2.3.2. Although research has shown that clade 2.3.4 viruses are established in poultry in Asia, the emergence of clade 2.3.2 viruses in non-passerine birds from Hong Kong, Japan, and Russia raises the possibility that this virus lineage may have become established in wild birds." (1)

"The black-faced spoonbill (_Platalea minor_) is a species of wading bird in the ibis and spoonbill family Threskiornithidae, found in eastern Asia. This species has the most restricted distribution of the 6 spoonbill species, and it is the only one regarded as endangered. Spoonbills are large water birds with dorso-ventrally flattened, spatulate bills. It currently breeds only on a few small rocky islands off the west coast of North Korea, with 4 wintering sites at Macau, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Viet Nam, as well as other places where they have been observed in migration. Wintering also occurs in Jeju, South Korea, Kyushu, and Okinawa, Japan, and the Red River delta in Viet Nam."
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black-faced_spoonbill>)

Images for black-faced spoonbill, Hong Kong can be seen at <https://www.alamy.com/black-faced-spoonbill-platalea-minor-nt-hong-kong-30th-oct-2011-image378782319.html>.

Reference
---------
1. Smith GJ, Vijaykrishna D, Ellis TM, et al. Characterization of avian influenza viruses A (H5N1) from wild birds, Hong Kong, 2004-2008. Emerg Infect Dis. 2009; 15:3, 402-7; <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19239752/>.
- Mod.TTM

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

Communicated by:
ProMED

[From 2014 onwards HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses caused outbreaks across the Eurasian region, affecting both poultry and wild birds, with abundant genetic reassortments yielding subtypes H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8. Regarding infection of these viruses in mammals, recently, HPAI H5N8 infections were reported in humans in Russia (see ProMED post 20210221.8204014). Several subtypes of AI viruses (H7N7, H4N5, H4N6, H3N3, and H10N7) have caused epidemics in harbour seals and gray seals, but they do not appear to become established in these carnivore species. Regarding terrestrial carnivores, red foxes have been shown to be susceptible to infection by HPAI H5N1, and there was recent documentation of a spill-over of HPAI H5N8 to wild carnivores. Virus evolution and adaptive mutations must be closely monitored to rapidly identify viruses with increased potential to infect mammals. - Mod.PMB

Affected population: a dead, black-faced spoonbill was collected on [16 Dec 2021] at the mudflat of Hong Kong Wetland Park. The species is a common winter visitor in Deep Bay areas with a small number recorded in summer.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: an intensive surveillance system is in place for all poultry farms, poultry markets, and pet bird shops in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected bird was detected in the ongoing territory wide surveillance program on wild birds. No spread of the disease was evident. There are 2 poultry farms located within 3 kilometers [2 mi] of where the bird was found. No abnormalities or signs of avian influenza were found in the 2 farms. The end date of the outbreak is the same as the date the bird was found (16 Dec 2021).

Control measures applied [in wild]: disinfection; screening
