summary: PRO/MBDS> Avian influenza, human (20): China (Sichuan) H5N6, fatal
content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (20): CHINA (SICHUAN) H5N6, FATAL
********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 8 Dec 2021
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-human-h5n6-avian-influenza-case-in-sichuan-province-27th-case-this-year-34601/>


Hong Kong health authorities report monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in a 54-year-old woman living in Zigong, Sichuan Province. The woman had exposure to deceased backyard poultry before the onset of symptoms. She developed symptoms on [17 Nov 2021], and was admitted for treatment on [21 Nov 2021] and passed away on [23 Nov 2021].

This is the 27th human case reported on Mainland China in the past year [2020] and the 52nd case reported since the first case was reported in 2014.

Avian influenza is caused by those influenza viruses that mainly affect birds and poultry, such as chickens or ducks.

Clinical presentation of avian influenza in humans includes eye infection (conjunctivitis), flu-like symptoms (e.g. fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches) or severe respiratory illness (e.g. chest infection). The incubation period ranges from 7 to 10 days.

The more virulent forms can result in respiratory failure, multi-organ failure and even death. People mainly become infected with avian influenza virus through contact with infected birds and poultry (live or dead) or their droppings, or contact with contaminated environments (such as wet markets and live poultry markets). Human-to-human transmission is inefficient.

People in close contact with poultry are more susceptible to contracting avian influenza. The elderly, children and people with chronic illness have a higher risk of developing complications such as bronchitis and chest infection.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MBDS
<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>

["Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. With continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans. Surveillance should be continued to detect human cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of the viruses." <https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20211119.pdf?sfvrsn=223ca73f_161#:~:text=To%20date%2C%20a%20total%20of,date%20of%2020%20October%202021>

"Ongoing global monitoring for respiratory viruses with pandemic potential has recently identified three new human infections with avian influenza A(H5N6) virus (or "A(H5N6) bird flu") in China. Reported influenza A(H5N6) virus infections during 2021 have doubled the number of such cases detected since this virus was first found in people in 2014, raising concerns about the risk of additional human zoonotic infections and the pandemic potential of this virus. In coordination with the World Health Organization Global Influenza Program, CDC and global partners reviewed laboratory and epidemiologic data for influenza A(H5N6) viruses as well as existing H5 candidate vaccine viruses (CVVs) to assess their relatedness to current influenza A(H5N6) viruses during September 2021. Based on current antigenic, genetic and epidemiologic data, it was determined that previously recommended H5 CVVs are still expected to offer protection against influenza A(H5N6) viruses should vaccination be needed." <https://www.cdc.gov/flu/spotlights/2021-2022/H5N6.htm>

For the map of China see: <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155>
- Mod.ST

ProMED map:
Sichuan Province, China: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700160,350>]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Many species of migratory waterfowl winter in India, and it is also year-round habitat for several resident waterfowl species. A recent study showed that HPAI outbreaks are strongly demarcated by wild waterfowl and their interface with domestic poultry in specific wetland habitat in India (<https://doi.org/10.3390/v12111290>). - Mod.PMB

Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Iran
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 25 Nov 2021
Confirmed: 28 Nov 2021
Reported: 29 Nov 2021
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 25 Nov 2021
Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]
Serotype: H5N8
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, necropsy, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

New outbreaks
Total outbreaks (2)
Outbreak location 1: Mighan lagoon, Arak, Markazi
Started: 25 Nov 2021
Epidemiological unit: natural park
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
[Greylag goose (_Anser anser_)] / 4000 / 2 / 0 / 2 / 0 / 0
Affected population: greylag goose

Outbreak location 2: Fereidun kenar wildlife refuge, Babolsar, Mazandaran
Started: 29 Nov 2021
Epidemiological unit: natural park
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
[Swan] / 700 / 1 / 1/ 0 / 0 / 0
Affected population: swan N-type has not been yet identified.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species.
Epidemiological comments: the event was reported according to the Iran passive surveillance in place.
A post-outbreak investigation to trace the source of infection is ongoing to detect the probable spread and circulation of this subtype. Active surveillance is ongoing

Control measures at event level
Domestic control measures applied: traceability; screening; quarantine; disinfection; disinfestation

Domestic control measures to be applied: surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result
Central Veterinary Reference laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (IVO) national laboratory / birds / 2 / real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / [28 Nov 2021] / positive

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Iran may represent a hotspot for HPAI virus introduction, dissemination, and for the generation of new genetic variability. This is supported by recent evidence (<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.meegid.2020.104342>).

The Black Sea/Mediterranean flyway runs through the northern Iranian territory and may contribute to spread westwards. Poultry trade must also be taken into account. - Mod.PMB

summary: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (169): Europe (France) poultry, HPAI H5N1, control
content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (169): EUROPE (FRANCE) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, CONTROL
******************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: Agrazeitungt/Feed Magazine [edited]
<https://www.agrarzeitung.de/feedmagazine/feedmagazine-news/france-avian-influenza-in-livestock-98593>


In France, the latest epidemic has hit a farm with laying hens. It is the 1st case in a commercial livestock farm.

According to the Ministry of Agriculture, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was detected last Friday [27 Nov 2021] on a laying hen farm in the Nord department, just a few kilometres from the Belgian border. Investigations were currently underway to trace the route of infection.

According to the ministry, the flock was culled and the farm immediately disinfected. A protection zone and a surveillance zone had been set up around the outbreak. This is connected with strict biosecurity regulations for poultry farmers and a transport ban for birds.

The alliance of the Confederation Paysanne (Conf), an association of small farmers, and the Federation of Organic Farmers (FNAB), meanwhile, stressed that the farm in question was a commercial one with 160 000 birds and was also located in a region with close links to Belgium, Germany, and the Netherlands. The organisations had jointly lodged a complaint with the Supreme Administrative Court in order to bring down the new disease protection requirements. Among other things, they see high hurdles for exemptions from the stall obligation endangering animal welfare and the existence of free-range farms.

According to Conf and FNAB, there is scientific evidence that the risk of introducing avian influenza into free-range systems is generally low. The spread of the disease depends mainly on the density of the flock, and the transport of goods and animals and the introduction of people also play an important role in the spread of the virus. It is also criticised that exemptions from the obligation to keep animals in confined areas are only possible if a veterinarian has previously certified that the animals are suffering from the disease.

In France, according to official data, 4 cases of avian influenza in wild birds and 3 cases in backyard flocks have been registered so far. Lac de Madine in the Grand-Est region [map at <tinyurl.com/2hsb33ah>] is currently experiencing high mortality in swans, according to the ministry. Of the population of more than 1000 individuals, about 1/5 have died, it said. The previous epidemic, which came to a halt only last spring, had been concentrated in the southwest of the country and affected 492 commercial livestock farms, according to the ministry. By official order, a total of about 3.5 million birds, mostly ducks, had been killed at the time [see comment].

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The above outbreak was reported by France to the OIE on Fri 27 Nov 2021, following the confirmation of HPAI H5N1 in the commercial laying hen farm on 26 Nov 2021; see item [10] in 20211205.8700016. The immediate notification included the following information on the affected population: "Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 deaths out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000 hens). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak, and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones is prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time."

The above media addresses the reservations of the farming industry, challenging the applied control and prevention measures. These measures are prescribed by EU legislation, based upon scientific opinion. Some of the measures have been recently reviewed; see Nielsen S S, Alvarez J, Bicout D J, et al. Scientific Opinion on the assessment of the control measures of the category A diseases of Animal Health Law: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza. EFSA Journal. 2021; 19(1): 6372, 78 pp; <https://doi.org/10.2903/j.efsa.2021.6372>.

The current epizootic, involving many European and other countries, is caused by HPAI H5N1. The earlier epizootic in France, mainly affecting the duck industry in the southwest, was caused by HPAI H5N8; see Guinat C, Artois J, Bronner A, et al. Duck production systems and highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 in France, 2016-2017. Sci Rep. 2019; 9: 6177; <https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-42607-x>. - Mod.AS

HealthMap/ProMED map of France: <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100>]

<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: JIJI Press News [edited]
<https://jen.jiji.com/jc/eng?g=eco&k=2021120300830>


The prefectural government of Kumamoto, southwestern Japan, said Friday [3 Dec 2021] that it has confirmed an outbreak of avian influenza believed to be highly pathogenic at a chicken farm in the town of Nankan.

It was this season's 5th fifth bird flu outbreak confirmed at a poultry farm in Japan and 1st in the prefecture.

The prefectural government will cull some 67 000 chickens at the farm. According to the prefecture, a local livestock health center received a report from the farm Thursday [2 Dec 2021] that an increasing number of chickens there had been found dead. After simple testing showed positive results, the bird flu virus was found likely to be highly pathogenic in genetic testing.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MBDS
<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>

[The newswire above provides no detailed information on the subtype of avian influenza virus at the outbreak farm.

According to Asahi Shimbun news dated 17 Nov 2021, "Japan has confirmed that the highly pathogenic bird flu subtype H5N8 was detected at a poultry farm in the 3rd outbreak of avian influenza in Kagoshima Prefecture this winter [2021]." (<https://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/14483303>)

OIE reported another HPAI H5N8 outbreak in wild birds in Kagoshima on 24 Nov 2021 (See ProMED archive 20211125.8699870).

"Currently, the H5N1, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6 and H5N8 subtypes of HPAI are circulating in bird and poultry populations across the globe, sparking concern at OIE which called this an "unprecedented genetic variability of subtypes...creating an epidemiologically challenging landscape." (<https://www.jpost.com/health-and-wellness/oie-urges-vigilance-as-bird-flu-outbreaks-spread-around-the-world-685562>)

"Kumamoto is the capital city of Kumamoto Prefecture on the island of Kyushu, Japan." (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumamoto>). - Mod.TTM

Source: Yonhap News Agency [edited]
<https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20211204001500320>


South Korea on Saturday [4 Dec 2021] reported suspected cases of highly pathogenic bird flu at a local egg farm.

The suspected cases of avian influenza were discovered at an egg farm in Cheonan, 92 km [57 mi] south of Seoul, according to the government's avian influenza response headquarters.

Tests for avian influenza are currently underway, and the results will be announced in up to 3 days, the headquarters said.

Highly pathogenic avian influenza is very contagious among birds and can cause severe illness and even death, especially in domestic poultry.

--

ProMED-MBDS
<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>

[The newswire above provides no detailed information on the avian influenza virus subtype, which will be announced in up to 3 days.

"Cheonan, also spelled Ch'ŏnan, is a city in South Chungcheong, South Korea. Cheonan has a population of 666 417 (2018), making it the most populous city or county in South Chungcheong, and the 3rd most populous city in the Hoseo region after Daejeon and Cheongju. Cheonan borders the Gyeonggi cities of Pyeongtaek and Anseong to the north, the South Chungcheong cities of Asan to the west and Gongju to the southwest, Sejong Special Autonomous City to the south, the North Chungcheong city of Cheongju to the south-east and Jincheon County to the east. "(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheonan>). - Mod.TTM

summary: PRO/RUS> Зарубежное эпизоотическое обозрение - высокопатогенный грипп птиц - Япония (2), Болгария (2)
content:
Зарубежное эпизоотическое обозрение - высокопатогенный грипп птиц - Япония (2), Болгария (2)
********************************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Дата: 05 декабря 2021 г

(1) Источник: regnum.ru, 04 декабря 2021 г.
<https://regnum.ru/news/3441279.html>
 
На юго-западе Японии из-за птичьего гриппа уничтожили 67 тыс. кур
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
По сообщению телеканала NHK.в префектуре Кумамото, расположенной на юго-западе Японии, из-за вспышки птичьего гриппа на местной ферме уничтожили около 67 тысяч кур. 
По его данным, за пределами очага - на территории других ферм в радиусе трёх километров от поражённой гриппом - у кур не было диагностировано симптомов заболевания. Что объясняется оперативно принятыми властями мерами, предотвратившими дальнейшее распространение инфекции.
Напомним, что в ноябре текущего года две вспышки птичьего гриппа привели к уничтожению 155 тысяч кур в префектуре Хёго и 11 тысяч кур - в префектуре Кагосима.
Как сообщало ИА REGNUM, на одной из ферм в южнокорейском уезде Дамян провинции Чолла-Намдо обнаружен высокопатогенный штамм птичьего гриппа.

(2) Источник: regnum.ru, 04 декабря 2021
<https://regnum.ru/news/3441555.html>
 
В Болгарии зарегистрирована вспышка «птичьего гриппа»
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
В Болгарии зарегистрированы три новых случая заболевания птичьим гриппом. Об этом 4 декабря со ссылкой на Национальное агентство по безопасности пищевых продуктов РБ сообщила софийская газета «Факты».
Согласно официальной информации, очаги эпидемии обнаружены в одном промышленном и двух частных фермерских хозяйствах в Пловдивской и Пазарджикской областях страны. На момент определения диагноза на крупной птицеферме содержались 80 000 кур, на крестьянских подворьях - около 100 птиц. В ближайшее время все поголовье пернатых будет уничтожено.
Как отметили представители Министерства здравоохранения Болгарии, подобная разновидность «птичьего гриппа» опасности для человека не представляет. Тем не менее, в указанных районах введены карантинные ограничения.
 
--
Communicated by:
ProMED-RUS
<promed-rus@promedmail.org>

[Комментарий Корр. ВМ. Вспышка птичьего гриппа осенью 2020 г. и весной 2021 г. стала самой масштабной в истории Японии. Тогда заболевание было зарегистрировано в более, чем в трети префектур Японии. Для ликвидации вспышки было уничтожено около 10 миллионов кур. Источник: <https://ria.ru/20211114/vspyshka-1759028840.html>
Очередная вспышка птичьего гриппа произошла в префектуре Кагосима в середине ноября. В куриных тушках был обнаружен высокопатогенный штамм Н5 птичьего гриппа. На ферме было уничтожено 38,5 тысячи птиц. Источник: <https://tass.ru/obschestvo/13110291>
В целом, за осенний сезон 2021 г. в Японии было в общей сложности зарегистрировано не менее 3 вспышек птичьего гриппа в
префектурах Хёго, Кагосима и Кумамото.
В феврале 2021 года на территории Болгарии была зарегистрирована вспышка высокопатогенного птичьего гриппа и было уничтожено 166 тысяч пекинских уток. Всего было сообщено о двух вспышках этого заболевания на двух птицефабриках в Болгарии, расположенных примерно в 190 км к северо-востоку от Софии. Источник: <https://www.rosbalt.ru/world/2021/02/05/1886162.html>. - Corr. VM]

[See Also:
Смотрите также: 
13 Nov 2021 Зарубежное эпизоотическое обозрение - высокопатогенный грипп птиц H5 - Япония (Кагосима) (9) 20211113.8699646
06 Feb 2021 Зарубежное эпизоотическое обозрение - высокопатогенный грипп птиц (Болгария, Франция (4)) 20210206.8171666]
.................................................ba/vm

Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones are prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time.

<promed@promedmail.org>

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43428>


Event started on 21 Nov 2021. A total of 1 outbreak (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a laying hen farm, Warhem, Dunkerque, Nord, Hauts-de-France.

Affected population: Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones are prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated

Event started on 21 Nov 2021. A total of 1 outbreak (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a laying hen farm, Warhem, Dunkerque, Nord, Hauts-de-France.

Affected population: Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones are prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 77 450 / 77 450 / 15 000 / - / 0 / 0

[13] Bulgaria (Plovdiv): poultry, wild bird, HPAI serotype pending
Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43762>


Event started on 15 Nov 2021. A total of 4 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI has been detected in poultry (3 outbreaks) and wild bird (1 outbreak) in the Plovdiv region.

The outbreaks are as follows:
Outbreak ID ob_93350 - HPAI was confirmed in a commercial farm with laying hens and rearing flocks. 
Outbreak ID ob_93343 - HPAI was confirmed in a backyard.
Outbreak ID ob_93342 - HPAI was confirmed in a farm.
Outbreak ID ob_93348 - HPAI was confirmed in the public hunting area in Trakiya, Chekeritsa.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 119 187 / 1 / 1113 / 118 074 / - / -
Phasianidae (unidentified) (Phasianidae (incognita)): Phasianidae-Galliformes / 685 / 205 / 205 / 480 / - / -

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

<promed@promedmail.org>

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

Event started on 21 Nov 2021. A total of 1 outbreak (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a laying hen farm, Warhem, Dunkerque, Nord, Hauts-de-France.

Affected population: Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones are prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated

[13] Bulgaria (Plovdiv): poultry, wild bird, HPAI serotype pending
Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43762>


Event started on 15 Nov 2021. A total of 4 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI has been detected in poultry (3 outbreaks) and wild bird (1 outbreak) in the Plovdiv region.

The outbreaks are as follows:
Outbreak ID ob_93350 - HPAI was confirmed in a commercial farm with laying hens and rearing flocks. 
Outbreak ID ob_93343 - HPAI was confirmed in a backyard.
Outbreak ID ob_93342 - HPAI was confirmed in a farm.
Outbreak ID ob_93348 - HPAI was confirmed in the public hunting area in Trakiya, Chekeritsa.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 119 187 / 1 / 1113 / 118 074 / - / -
Phasianidae (unidentified) (Phasianidae (incognita)): Phasianidae-Galliformes / 685 / 205 / 205 / 480 / - / -

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

Event started on 21 Nov 2021. A total of 1 outbreak (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a laying hen farm, Warhem, Dunkerque, Nord, Hauts-de-France.

Affected population: Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones are prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 77 450 / 77 450 / 15 000 / - / 0 / 0

[13] Bulgaria (Plovdiv): poultry, wild bird, HPAI serotype pending
Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43762>


Event started on 15 Nov 2021. A total of 4 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI has been detected in poultry (3 outbreaks) and wild bird (1 outbreak) in the Plovdiv region.

The outbreaks are as follows:
Outbreak ID ob_93350 - HPAI was confirmed in a commercial farm with laying hens and rearing flocks. 
Outbreak ID ob_93343 - HPAI was confirmed in a backyard.
Outbreak ID ob_93342 - HPAI was confirmed in a farm.
Outbreak ID ob_93348 - HPAI was confirmed in the public hunting area in Trakiya, Chekeritsa.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 119 187 / 1 / 1113 / 118 074 / - / -
Phasianidae (unidentified) (Phasianidae (incognita)): Phasianidae-Galliformes / 685 / 205 / 205 / 480 / - / -

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

<promed@promedmail.org>

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

[15] Croatia (Sisacko-Moslavacka): wild bird, HPAI H5N1
Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43707>
 

Event started on 12 Nov 2021. A total of 2 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in 7 mute swans (_Cygnus olor_) in the nature park of Lonjsko Polje, Sisacko-Moslavacka County.

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43428>


Event started on 21 Nov 2021. A total of 1 outbreak (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a laying hen farm, Warhem, Dunkerque, Nord, Hauts-de-France.

Affected population: Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones are prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 77 450 / 77 450 / 15 000 / - / 0 / 0

[13] Bulgaria (Plovdiv): poultry, wild bird, HPAI serotype pending
Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43762>


Event started on 15 Nov 2021. A total of 4 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI has been detected in poultry (3 outbreaks) and wild bird (1 outbreak) in the Plovdiv region.

The outbreaks are as follows:
Outbreak ID ob_93350 - HPAI was confirmed in a commercial farm with laying hens and rearing flocks. 
Outbreak ID ob_93343 - HPAI was confirmed in a backyard.
Outbreak ID ob_93342 - HPAI was confirmed in a farm.
Outbreak ID ob_93348 - HPAI was confirmed in the public hunting area in Trakiya, Chekeritsa.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 119 187 / 1 / 1113 / 118 074 / - / -
Phasianidae (unidentified) (Phasianidae (incognita)): Phasianidae-Galliformes / 685 / 205 / 205 / 480 / - / -

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

Event started on 21 Nov 2021. A total of 1 outbreak (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a laying hen farm, Warhem, Dunkerque, Nord, Hauts-de-France.

Affected population: Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones are prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 77 450 / 77 450 / 15 000 / - / 0 / 0

[13] Bulgaria (Plovdiv): poultry, wild bird, HPAI serotype pending
Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43762>


Event started on 15 Nov 2021. A total of 4 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI has been detected in poultry (3 outbreaks) and wild bird (1 outbreak) in the Plovdiv region.

The outbreaks are as follows:
Outbreak ID ob_93350 - HPAI was confirmed in a commercial farm with laying hens and rearing flocks. 
Outbreak ID ob_93343 - HPAI was confirmed in a backyard.
Outbreak ID ob_93342 - HPAI was confirmed in a farm.
Outbreak ID ob_93348 - HPAI was confirmed in the public hunting area in Trakiya, Chekeritsa.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 119 187 / 1 / 1113 / 118 074 / - / -
Phasianidae (unidentified) (Phasianidae (incognita)): Phasianidae-Galliformes / 685 / 205 / 205 / 480 / - / -

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

Affected population: Anserinae (unidentified) (Anserinae (unidentified)) (1 case) and Cygnus (unidentified) (Cygnus (incognita)) (4 cases).

Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43428>


Event started on 21 Nov 2021. A total of 1 outbreak (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a laying hen farm, Warhem, Dunkerque, Nord, Hauts-de-France.

Affected population: Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones are prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 77 450 / 77 450 / 15 000 / - / 0 / 0

- One Greylag goose (_Anser anser_) found dead close to a lake in Remich, Grevenmacher.

[13] Bulgaria (Plovdiv): poultry, wild bird, HPAI serotype pending
Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43762>


Event started on 15 Nov 2021. A total of 4 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI has been detected in poultry (3 outbreaks) and wild bird (1 outbreak) in the Plovdiv region.

The outbreaks are as follows:
Outbreak ID ob_93350 - HPAI was confirmed in a commercial farm with laying hens and rearing flocks. 
Outbreak ID ob_93343 - HPAI was confirmed in a backyard.
Outbreak ID ob_93342 - HPAI was confirmed in a farm.
Outbreak ID ob_93348 - HPAI was confirmed in the public hunting area in Trakiya, Chekeritsa.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Birds / 119 187 / 1 / 1113 / 118 074 / - / -
Phasianidae (unidentified) (Phasianidae (incognita)): Phasianidae-Galliformes / 685 / 205 / 205 / 480 / - / -

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (<https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/>), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]

[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at <https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf>, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. 

According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. 

A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327>) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRD

content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (23): ISRAEL (HAMERKAZ) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, OIE /انفلونزا الطيور (23) : اسرائيل (هامركاز) ، طيور برية، المنظمه العالمية للصحة الحيوانية 
*****************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43604>


Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Israel
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: Immediate notification
Started: 29 Nov 2021
Confirmed: 30 Nov 2021
Reported: 1 Dec 2021
Reason for notification: Recurrence
Last occurrence: 9 Apr 2021
Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]
Serotype: H5N1
Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Mishmar Hasharon, HaMerkaz
Started: 29 Nov 2021
Epidemiological unit: Natural park
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Great white pelican (_Pelecanus onocrotalus_): Pelecanidae-Phaethontiformes / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0
Affected population: The pelican was found near a water pond. It was transferred to the wildlife hospital and died there.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Contact with wild species
Epidemiological comments: Several outbreaks in poultry have occurred in Israel in the past few weeks. The hypothesis is that the domestic birds are infected by fomites sourced from wild birds. Israel is a migration route for about 500 million birds twice a year between Africa and Asia. The pond where the pelican was found is about 20 km [12.4 mi] from one of the outbreaks in poultry (Maayan Zvi).

Control measures at event level
Wild control measures to be applied: Surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone
Additional measures: Zoning, disinfection

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result
Kimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Division (national laboratory) / Birds / 1 / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 1 Dec 2021 / Positive
Northern Poultry Health Laboratory (regional laboratory) / Birds / 1 / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [12-13 Oct 2021] / Positive
Kimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Division (national laboratory) / Birds / 1 / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [12-13 Oct 2021] / Positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-MENA
<promed-mena@promedmail.org>
via
ProMED
<promed@promedmail.org>

[The great white pelican (_Pelecanus onocrotalus_) is a huge bird that breeds from southeastern Europe through Asia and Africa, in swamps and shallow lakes. It is highly sociable and often forms large flocks. Wintering takes place in northeastern Africa through Iraq to north India, with a particularly large number of breeders from Asia wintering around Pakistan and Sri Lanka. - Mod.PMB

The location of the water pond where the sick pelican was collected is available at <http://tinyurl.com/bdhb59pm>. This is one of 2 water bodies, countrywide, that have become "pelican-friendly reservoirs" within a cooperative effort by Israel's Ministry of Agriculture (fisheries division), the Fish Farmers' Organization, the National Parks & Nature Reserves, and respective regional municipalities, to minimise the friction between man and pelican. Until 2012, serious economic losses caused by the pelicans to fish farms compelled farmers to take drastic measures driving the birds away. Since 2013, the pelicans, mostly arriving in October and staying to early December, are provided in the 2 locations a substitute food source. Tonnes of second-rate fish that are destined to be thrown away/recycled because they are not commercial while the ponds are seasonally emptied, are purchased at the cost of labor and transportation and moved to the 2 reservoirs (the other one is in northern Israel). A byproduct is reducing hazard to air traffic by encouraging the birds to remain, before continuing their flight to Africa, at a single location (<https://www.iaf.org.il/4374-38053-EN/IAF.aspx>).

Israel's "when and where" regarding the great white pelican is available at <https://www.birds.org.il/en/species-page/95/species-trends>.

A recent feeding session of the pelicans, late October 2021, can be viewed at <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dcnxFsfmC-c>.

The thousands of pelicans in the Mishmar Hasharon reservoir have become, during the current and previous seasons, a national public attraction. During their recent stay, terminating at this time (early December), no overt disease or excessive deaths have been reported. The detection of a single HPAI H5N1 sick, infected bird (date of its initial collection not available) underlines the need for an enhanced One Health approach, including animal and public health authorities, ornithologists, nature protection and water supply agencies, during the seasons ahead. - Mod.AS

Detailed information about avian and other zoonotic influenza can be found at <http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/avian_influenza/en/>. - Mod.SMA

HealthMap/ProMED map of HaMerkaz, Israel: <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/17787>]

summary: PRO/RUS> Высокопатогенный грипп птиц - Россия (Республика Башкортостан (3)), Евросоюз
content:
Высокопатогенный грипп птиц - Россия (Республика Башкортостан (3)), Евросоюз
*****************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Дата: 03 декабря 2021 г.

(1) Источник: interfax-russia.ru, 03 декабря 2021 г. 
<https://ufacitynews.ru/news/2021/12/03/v-rajone-bashkirii-iz-za-ptichego-grippa-vveli-rezhim-chs>

В районе Башкирии из-за птичьего гриппа ввели режим ЧС
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
В Госкомитете РБ по ЧС рассказали об обстановке на территории республики за прошедшие сутки.
В Благоварском районе ввели режим ЧС, который действует до сих пор, из-за выявленных случаев птичьего гриппа. Режим «Чрезвычайная ситуация» установлен и в Баймакском районе, где среди крупного рогатого скота нашли узелковый дерматит.
Напомним, что ранее птичий грипп был выявлен в двух населенных пунктах Туймазинского района.

(2) Источник: meatinfo.ru, 03 декабря 2021 г. 
<https://meatinfo.ru/news/ptichiy-gripp-shagaet-po-evrope-429019>

Птичий грипп шагает по Европе
--------------------------------------------
Птичий грипп продолжает оставаться серьезной проблемой для птицеводов по всей Европе. За последние два месяца о вспышках болезни сообщалось в Польше, Англии, Франции, Венгрии, Нидерландах, Ирландии и Италии, последнее - вспышка, обнаруженная у лебедей недалеко от Рима. В Венгрии 5000 индеек на ферме в графстве Бекеш были убиты в начале этой недели из-за вспышки высокопатогенного вируса птичьего гриппа H5N1.
Две недели назад из-за вспышки птичьего гриппа в южном районе Бач-Кишкун на одной ферме было отбраковано более 38 000 уток, а на второй - около 500 гусей.
Франция также подтвердила на прошлой неделе наличие вируса на птицефабрике недалеко от бельгийской границы. Вирус анализируется Французским агентством по продовольствию, окружающей среде и охране труда. Все птицы на пораженной ферме в северо-западном городе Вархем будут отбракованы, а также установлен 10-километровый периметр наблюдения, при котором любое перемещение домашней птицы в этом районе запрещено.
Часть ограниченной территории находится в бельгийской провинции Западная Фландрия. Федеральное агентство Бельгии по безопасности пищевой цепи сегодня приняло дополнительные меры для городов Де Панн, Верн, Альверингем и Поперинг. Птицеводы и частные владельцы должны держать птиц в клетках, а выставки и ярмарки птицы запрещены.
Власти Великобритании также сообщили о 5 вспышках на коммерческих фермах, и птицеводам по всему королевству рекомендовано держать птицу в помещениях, чтобы предотвратить распространение вируса. Власти Ирландии сообщили о трех вспышках за последние 30 дней.
В Италии самый большой парк Рима был частично закрыт для посещения после того, как лебедь умер от птичьего гриппа. Об этом сообщил в понедельник вечером мэр города Роберто Гуальтьери, который приказал закрыть на 10 дней восточную часть виллы Памфили в районе озера Джильо.
В ноябре власти Польши сообщили о более чем 25 вспышках, и отрасль может столкнуться с еще одним плохим сезоном из-за ограничений, введенных странами за пределами ЕС. Польша также является крупнейшим производителем мяса птицы в ЕС с долей рынка 19%. 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-RUS
<promed-rus@promedmail.org>

[Комментарий Корр. ВМ. В настоящее время эпизоотическая ситуация по гриппу птиц на территории Российской Федерации продолжает оставаться напряженной. По данным МЭБ, по состоянию на 22 ноября 2021 года в стране были зарегистрировано 57 вспышек высокопатогенного гриппа птиц в 18 субъектах страны. Источник: <https://cap.ru/news/2021/12/03/epizooticheskaya-situaciya-po-grippu-ptic-na-terri>.
В Республике Башкортостан планируется вакцинации сельскохозяйственных птиц от высокопатогенного гриппа птиц. Поголовная иммунизация необходима для предупреждения заражения сельскохозяйственных птиц от перелетных птиц, как это произошло осенью текущего года в Благоварском и Туймазинском районах. Тогда в результате заражения было уничтожены тысячи голов гусей, уток и кур на фермах и в личных хозяйствах. Вакцинации подлежит не только поголовье на птицефермах, но и птица в частных хозяйствах.  Источник: <https://tuvest.ru/news/novosti/2021-12-03/v-bashkirii-vaktsiniruyut-vse-pogolovie-ptitsy-iz-za-vspyshek-ptichiego-grippa-2605232>. - Corr. VM]

[See Also:
Смотрите также: 
20 Nov 2021 Высокопатогенный грипп птиц - Россия (Башкортостан) (2), Израиль (2) 20211120.8699786
08 Oct 2021 Высокопатогенный грипп птиц - Россия (Тюменская (5), Самарская области, Республика Башкортостан) 20211008.8698930
01 Dec 2021 Avian influenza (165): Europe (UK) poultry, wild, HPAI H5N1, spread 20211201.8699982]
.................................................ba/vm

summary: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (167): Israel (HM) wild bird, HPAI H5N1, OIE
content:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (167): ISRAEL (HAMERKAZ) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, OIE
******************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Dec 2021
Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]
<https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43604>


Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Israel
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 29 Nov 2021
Confirmed: 30 Nov 2021
Reported: 1 Dec 2021
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 9 Apr 2021
Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]
Serotype: H5N1
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Mishmar Hasharon, HaMerkaz
Started: 29 Nov 2021
Epidemiological unit: natural park
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Great white pelican (_Pelecanus onocrotalus_): Pelecanidae-Phaethontiformes / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0
Affected population: the pelican was found near a water pond. It was transferred to the wildlife hospital and died there.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species.
Epidemiological comments: several outbreaks in poultry have occurred in Israel in the past few weeks. The hypothesis is that the domestic birds are infected by fomites sourced from wild birds. Israel is a migration route for about 500 million birds twice a year between Africa and Asia. The pond where the pelican was found is about 20 km [12.4 mi] from one of the outbreaks in poultry (Maayan Zvi).

Control measures at event level
Wild control measures to be applied: surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone
Additional measures: zoning, disinfection

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result
Kimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Division (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 1 Dec 2021 / positive
Northern Poultry Health Laboratory (regional laboratory) / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [12-13 Oct 2021] / positive
Kimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Division (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [12-13 Oct 2021] / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The great white pelican (_Pelecanus onocrotalus_) is a huge bird that breeds from southeastern Europe through Asia and Africa, in swamps and shallow lakes. It is highly sociable and often forms large flocks. Wintering takes place in northeastern Africa through Iraq to north India, with a particularly large number of breeders from Asia wintering around Pakistan and Sri Lanka. - Mod.PMB

The location of the water pond where the sick pelican was collected is available at <http://tinyurl.com/bdhb59pm>. This is one of 2 water bodies, countrywide, that have become "pelican-friendly reservoirs" within a cooperative effort by Israel's Ministry of Agriculture (fisheries division), the Fish Farmers' Organization, the National Parks & Nature Reserves, and respective regional municipalities, to minimise the friction between man and pelican. Until 2012, serious economic losses caused by the pelicans to fish farms compelled farmers to take drastic measures driving the birds away. Since 2013, the pelicans, mostly arriving in October and staying to early December, are provided in the 2 locations a substitute food source. Tonnes of second-rate fish that are destined to be thrown away/recycled because they are not commercial while the ponds are seasonally emptied, are purchased at the cost of labor and transportation and moved to the 2 reservoirs (the other one is in northern Israel). A byproduct is reducing hazard to air traffic by encouraging the birds to remain, before continuing their flight to Africa, at a single location (<https://www.iaf.org.il/4374-38053-EN/IAF.aspx>).

Israel's "when and where" regarding the great white pelican is available at <https://www.birds.org.il/en/species-page/95/species-trends>.

A recent feeding session of the pelicans, late October 2021, can be viewed at <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dcnxFsfmC-c>.

The thousands of pelicans in the Mishmar Hasharon reservoir have become, during the current and previous seasons, a national public attraction. During their recent stay, terminating at this time (early December), no overt disease or excessive deaths have been reported. The detection of a single HPAI H5N1 sick, infected bird (date of its initial collection not available) underlines the need for an enhanced One Health approach, including animal and public health authorities, ornithologists, nature protection and water supply agencies, during the seasons ahead. - Mod.AS

HealthMap/ProMED map of HaMerkaz, Israel: <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/17787>]

[See Also:
